items.title: Rural healthcare in crisis: New report reveals $8.35b funding gap
items.standfirst: Lives are at risk and rural GPs are working with ‘almost non-existent’ services – a new report lays bare the ballooning funding shortfall facing rural patients and doctors alike.
items.content: Lives are at risk and rural GPs are working with ‘almost non-existent’ services – a new report lays bare the ballooning funding shortfall facing rural patients and doctors alike.

ai_summary: A new report reveals a significant funding shortfall impacting rural patients and doctors.
Rural GPs are reportedly working with services that are almost non-existent.
The funding gap is contributing to lives being at risk in rural communities.
The report highlights the ballooning financial challenges facing rural healthcare providers.
The report underscores the urgent need for increased funding to support rural healthcare.

clusters.title: Children to be offered chickenpox vaccine on NHS
clusters.neutral_headline: Chickenpox vaccine offered to children in England

items.title: Children to be offered chickenpox vaccine on NHS
items.standfirst: All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026.
items.content: All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026.

items.title: Why is chickenpox vaccination being offered to children in England next year?
items.standfirst: Free NHS vaccination is aimed at reducing hospital admissions and protecting those most at risk of complicationsFor the first time, a free chickenpox vaccination will be offered to children in England by the NHS from January next year. Here we explore the background to the rollout. Continue reading...
items.content: Free NHS vaccination is aimed at reducing hospital admissions and protecting those most at risk of complicationsFor the first time, a free chickenpox vaccination will be offered to children in England by the NHS from January next year. Here we explore the background to the rollout. Continue reading...

items.title: What is chickenpox and how can I get my child vaccinated?
items.standfirst: The NHS in England and Wales will start offering the MMRV vaccine to young children from January 2026.
items.content: The NHS in England and Wales will start offering the MMRV vaccine to young children from January 2026.

items.title: Chickenpox jabs introduced as experts warn many children in England start school without vaccinations
items.standfirst: Experts say country needs ‘wake-up call’, while NHS will offer childhood chickenpox jab for first timeWhy is chickenpox vaccination being offered on NHS?England needs to “wake up” to its faltering infant vaccination programme, experts have warned, as it was revealed that one in five children start primary school unprotected from serious infectious diseases.It comes as the government announces a new vaccination programme for chickenpox from January, meaning that GPs will offer eligible children a combined vaccine for measles, mumps, rubella and varicella – the clinical term for chickenpox – as part of the routine infant vaccination schedule. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say country needs ‘wake-up call’, while NHS will offer childhood chickenpox jab for first timeWhy is chickenpox vaccination being offered on NHS?England needs to “wake up” to its faltering infant vaccination programme, experts have warned, as it was revealed that one in five children start primary school unprotected from serious infectious diseases.It comes as the government announces a new vaccination programme for chickenpox from January, meaning that GPs will offer eligible children a combined vaccine for measles, mumps, rubella and varicella – the clinical term for chickenpox – as part of the routine infant vaccination schedule. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS in England and Wales will offer a free chickenpox vaccine from January 2026.
The vaccine will be the MMRV vaccine, which also covers measles, mumps, and rubella.
The program aims to reduce hospital admissions related to chickenpox complications.
Experts are concerned about the low vaccination rates in England.
The new program will be part of the routine infant vaccination schedule.

clusters.title: Mounjaro maker pauses shipments of weight loss drug to UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Mounjaro maker pauses shipments of weight loss drug to UK

items.title: Mounjaro maker pauses shipments of weight loss drug to UK
items.standfirst: US firm Eli Lilly reportedly tells British wholesalers to stop taking orders as demand soars before September price riseThe manufacturer of the weight-loss drug Mounjaro has paused shipments to the UK before a significant price rise for the treatment next month.The US pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is due to increase the UK list price of the drug by up to 170% from September amid a White House push to get drugmakers to raise medicine prices in Europe to allow for price cuts in the US. Continue reading...
items.content: US firm Eli Lilly reportedly tells British wholesalers to stop taking orders as demand soars before September price riseThe manufacturer of the weight-loss drug Mounjaro has paused shipments to the UK before a significant price rise for the treatment next month.The US pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is due to increase the UK list price of the drug by up to 170% from September amid a White House push to get drugmakers to raise medicine prices in Europe to allow for price cuts in the US. Continue reading...

items.title: Patients struggle to get weight loss drug ahead of price rise

items.content: The drug's US manufacturer has asked UK distributors to stop taking orders from pharmacies until next month's price increase.

ai_summary: Eli Lilly, the manufacturer of Mounjaro, has paused shipments to the UK.
The pause is due to a surge in demand before a price increase.
The price of Mounjaro is set to increase significantly in September.
The price increase is part of a push to raise medicine prices in Europe.
Patients are struggling to access the drug before the price rise.

clusters.title: Experience: I see the world through a layer of snow
clusters.neutral_headline: Experiencing visual snow syndrome

items.title: Experience: I see the world through a layer of snow
items.standfirst: My condition has a name – visual snow syndrome – and it could be with me for the rest of my lifeIt was in February of this year that I first noticed something wasn’t right. I was coming to the end of my maternity leave with my second child, and had recently retrained from being a wedding cake-maker to a food stylist, something I loved. As well as looking after two kids with my husband, Chris, I was picking up lots of work. I was probably juggling too much, but life was exciting.That week, I’d just finished a big job and was exhausted. I began to notice flashing lights in my vision. I assumed it was a migraine from overworking – I used to get them as a teenager – and didn’t think too much of it. Continue reading...
items.content: My condition has a name – visual snow syndrome – and it could be with me for the rest of my lifeIt was in February of this year that I first noticed something wasn’t right. I was coming to the end of my maternity leave with my second child, and had recently retrained from being a wedding cake-maker to a food stylist, something I loved. As well as looking after two kids with my husband, Chris, I was picking up lots of work. I was probably juggling too much, but life was exciting.That week, I’d just finished a big job and was exhausted. I began to notice flashing lights in my vision. I assumed it was a migraine from overworking – I used to get them as a teenager – and didn’t think too much of it. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author describes experiencing visual snow syndrome.
The condition causes a constant visual disturbance.
The author noticed the symptoms after maternity leave.
The author was juggling multiple responsibilities at the time.
The author initially thought the symptoms were related to migraines.

clusters.title: White House picks Kennedy deputy Jim O’Neill to replace fired CDC chief
clusters.neutral_headline: White House picks Kennedy deputy Jim O’Neill to replace fired CDC chief

items.title: White House picks Kennedy deputy Jim O’Neill to replace fired CDC chief
items.standfirst: Deputy health secretary chosen as agency’s interim director after firing of Susan MonarezWho’s who in the CDC crisis?The White House has chosen a deputy of Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve as the acting head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), a decision that comes as the standoff over the firing of director Susan Monarez has deepened, with Monarez’s lawyers claiming she will not depart unless Donald Trump himself removes her.A White House official confirmed to the Guardian that Jim O’Neill, currently the deputy secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), had been selected to temporarily lead the public health agency, giving Kennedy an ally in his efforts to overhaul US vaccine policy. Continue reading...
items.content: Deputy health secretary chosen as agency’s interim director after firing of Susan MonarezWho’s who in the CDC crisis?The White House has chosen a deputy of Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve as the acting head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), a decision that comes as the standoff over the firing of director Susan Monarez has deepened, with Monarez’s lawyers claiming she will not depart unless Donald Trump himself removes her.A White House official confirmed to the Guardian that Jim O’Neill, currently the deputy secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), had been selected to temporarily lead the public health agency, giving Kennedy an ally in his efforts to overhaul US vaccine policy. Continue reading...

items.title: CDC officials who quit in protest lead call to ‘get politics out of public health’
items.standfirst: Staffers gather in Atlanta to applaud senior leaders who resigned after CDC chief Susan Monarez was firedWho’s who in the CDC crisis?Senior CDC vaccine research and public health leaders who resigned in protest told hundreds of supporters across the street from the campus on Thursday that the Trump administration needs to “get politics out of public health”.The agency is reeling from the firing of the CDC chief, Susan Monarez, but Monarez, who was confirmed as CDC chief just a month ago, has refused to be removed. Three senior leaders – Debra Houry, Demetre Daskalakis and Daniel Jernigan – resigned shortly after in protest, citing the alleged spread of misinformation under the Trump administration and political interference in their work. The staffers cheered and applauded them at the event on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Staffers gather in Atlanta to applaud senior leaders who resigned after CDC chief Susan Monarez was firedWho’s who in the CDC crisis?Senior CDC vaccine research and public health leaders who resigned in protest told hundreds of supporters across the street from the campus on Thursday that the Trump administration needs to “get politics out of public health”.The agency is reeling from the firing of the CDC chief, Susan Monarez, but Monarez, who was confirmed as CDC chief just a month ago, has refused to be removed. Three senior leaders – Debra Houry, Demetre Daskalakis and Daniel Jernigan – resigned shortly after in protest, citing the alleged spread of misinformation under the Trump administration and political interference in their work. The staffers cheered and applauded them at the event on Thursday. Continue reading...

items.title: CDC erupts in chaos after ousted chief Susan Monarez refuses to resign
items.standfirst: Lawyers for Monarez say she was ‘targeted’ for ‘protecting the public’ by not endorsing ‘unscientific’ ordersThe US’s top public health agency was plunged into chaos on Wednesday after the Trump administration moved to oust its leader Susan Monarez, sworn in less than a month ago, as her lawyers said she would not resign and that she was being “targeted” for her pro-science stance.Monarez, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), was ousted on Wednesday evening, according to a statement from Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) that offered no explanation for its decision. Continue reading...
items.content: Lawyers for Monarez say she was ‘targeted’ for ‘protecting the public’ by not endorsing ‘unscientific’ ordersThe US’s top public health agency was plunged into chaos on Wednesday after the Trump administration moved to oust its leader Susan Monarez, sworn in less than a month ago, as her lawyers said she would not resign and that she was being “targeted” for her pro-science stance.Monarez, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), was ousted on Wednesday evening, according to a statement from Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) that offered no explanation for its decision. Continue reading...

items.title: CDC chief ‘targeted’ for refusing to ‘rubber-stamp unscientific, reckless directives’, lawyers say – as it happened
items.standfirst: This liveblog is now closed. Read the full story at the link below:CDC director Susan Monarez ousted after less than one month in the jobThis concludes our live coverage of the second Trump administration for the day, but we will be back at it on Thursday morning. Here are the latest developments:The leadership of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was thrown into chaos after the health department announced the Senate-confirmed CDC director, Susan Monarez, was no longer in charge, but her lawyers said she refused to resign and had not been fired.First it was independent advisory committees and career experts. Then it was the dismissal of seasoned scientists. Now, Robert F Kennedy Jr and HHS have set their sights on “weaponizing public health for political gain” and “putting millions of American lives at risk”, lawyers for Monarez said in a statement. “When CDC Director Susan Monarez refused to rubber-stamp unscientific, reckless directives and fire dedicated health experts, she chose protecting the public over serving a political agenda. For that, she has been targeted. Dr. Monarez has neither resigned nor received notification from the White House that she has been fired, and as a person of integrity and devoted to science, she will not resign.”At least three CDC senior officials resigned after Monarez was ousted. One squarely blamed Robert F Kennedy Jr’s leadership.“I am not able to serve in this role any longer because of the ongoing weaponization of public health,” Dr Demetre Daskalakis, who resigned as director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases told colleagues.Public health experts are sounding the alarm about the chaos at the CDC, as at least three senior leaders resigned following the ouster of the apparent ouster of the CDC director.As a Senate-confirmed official, only the president has the authority to fire her, and, for once, Donald Trump has been strangely silent as this drams unfolded. But the White House press office issued a statement saying that Monarez had been removed, not by Trump but by “the White House”. Continue reading...
items.content: This liveblog is now closed. Read the full story at the link below:CDC director Susan Monarez ousted after less than one month in the jobThis concludes our live coverage of the second Trump administration for the day, but we will be back at it on Thursday morning. Here are the latest developments:The leadership of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was thrown into chaos after the health department announced the Senate-confirmed CDC director, Susan Monarez, was no longer in charge, but her lawyers said she refused to resign and had not been fired.First it was independent advisory committees and career experts. Then it was the dismissal of seasoned scientists. Now, Robert F Kennedy Jr and HHS have set their sights on “weaponizing public health for political gain” and “putting millions of American lives at risk”, lawyers for Monarez said in a statement. “When CDC Director Susan Monarez refused to rubber-stamp unscientific, reckless directives and fire dedicated health experts, she chose protecting the public over serving a political agenda. For that, she has been targeted. Dr. Monarez has neither resigned nor received notification from the White House that she has been fired, and as a person of integrity and devoted to science, she will not resign.”At least three CDC senior officials resigned after Monarez was ousted. One squarely blamed Robert F Kennedy Jr’s leadership.“I am not able to serve in this role any longer because of the ongoing weaponization of public health,” Dr Demetre Daskalakis, who resigned as director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases told colleagues.Public health experts are sounding the alarm about the chaos at the CDC, as at least three senior leaders resigned following the ouster of the apparent ouster of the CDC director.As a Senate-confirmed official, only the president has the authority to fire her, and, for once, Donald Trump has been strangely silent as this drams unfolded. But the White House press office issued a statement saying that Monarez had been removed, not by Trump but by “the White House”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The White House appointed Jim O'Neill as interim CDC director.
O'Neill is currently the deputy secretary of Health and Human Services.
The appointment follows the firing of CDC chief Susan Monarez.
Monarez's lawyers claim she was targeted for protecting public health.
Senior CDC leaders resigned in protest of political interference.

clusters.title: Older autistic people need more help after years of misdiagnosis, review finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Older autistic people need more help after misdiagnosis

items.title: Older autistic people need more help after years of misdiagnosis, review finds
items.standfirst: Research estimates 90% of Britons over 50 with autism aren’t getting right treatment and face added difficultiesResearchers have called for better support for middle-aged and older autistic people after a review found that 90% of autistic people aged over 50 in Britain are either undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.Greater awareness of autism and improved assessments globally mean it is typically spotted in childhood today. But in past decades autistic people were often forced to navigate middle and old age without the support a diagnosis can unlock. Continue reading...
items.content: Research estimates 90% of Britons over 50 with autism aren’t getting right treatment and face added difficultiesResearchers have called for better support for middle-aged and older autistic people after a review found that 90% of autistic people aged over 50 in Britain are either undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.Greater awareness of autism and improved assessments globally mean it is typically spotted in childhood today. But in past decades autistic people were often forced to navigate middle and old age without the support a diagnosis can unlock. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A review found that many older autistic people are undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.
An estimated 90% of autistic people over 50 in Britain are affected.
Greater awareness has led to earlier diagnoses in recent years.
Older individuals may have missed out on crucial support.
The research calls for improved support for older autistic individuals.

People 65 and older are automatically eligible for the vaccines.
Younger people are eligible if they have underlying medical conditions.
The government will not recommend widespread vaccinations this season.

clusters.title: Shingles jab may reduce risk of heart attack, pioneering research reveals
clusters.neutral_headline: Shingles jab may reduce risk of heart attack, pioneering research reveals

items.title: Shingles jab may reduce risk of heart attack, pioneering research reveals
items.standfirst: First global systematic review finds vaccine associated with 18% lower risk of stroke or heart attack in adultsGetting the shingles vaccine could lower your risk of a heart attack or stroke by as much as 20%, according to the first study of its kind.Shingles is a common condition affecting millions worldwide that causes a painful rash and can lead to serious problems such as deafness, long-lasting pain and blindness. It is more likely to cause serious problems in older age groups. Continue reading...
items.content: First global systematic review finds vaccine associated with 18% lower risk of stroke or heart attack in adultsGetting the shingles vaccine could lower your risk of a heart attack or stroke by as much as 20%, according to the first study of its kind.Shingles is a common condition affecting millions worldwide that causes a painful rash and can lead to serious problems such as deafness, long-lasting pain and blindness. It is more likely to cause serious problems in older age groups. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research suggests the shingles vaccine may lower heart attack risk.
The study found an 18% lower risk of stroke or heart attack.
Shingles can cause serious health problems, especially in older adults.
The vaccine could potentially reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
The study is the first global systematic review of its kind.

clusters.title: Swallowing correctly can save your life – are you doing it right?
clusters.neutral_headline: Swallowing correctly can save your life – are you doing it right?

items.title: Swallowing correctly can save your life – are you doing it right?
items.standfirst: The natural movement may be different for everyone, and being mindful could help prevent, or resolve, dysphagiaShare your stories of caregiving for your parents with your siblingsPeople often assume swallowing is automatic and infallible, but I’ve learned it isn’t.When my daughter was two months old, she caught RSV and stopped gaining weight. When she tried to feed, she coughed and sputtered, sometimes arching her back. She was soon diagnosed with dysphagia – a swallowing disorder. Continue reading...
items.content: The natural movement may be different for everyone, and being mindful could help prevent, or resolve, dysphagiaShare your stories of caregiving for your parents with your siblingsPeople often assume swallowing is automatic and infallible, but I’ve learned it isn’t.When my daughter was two months old, she caught RSV and stopped gaining weight. When she tried to feed, she coughed and sputtered, sometimes arching her back. She was soon diagnosed with dysphagia – a swallowing disorder. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the importance of proper swallowing.
Swallowing is often assumed to be automatic and infallible.
The author's daughter was diagnosed with a swallowing disorder.

Being mindful of swallowing can help prevent or resolve issues.

items.title: People in England: share your experiences accessing NHS dental services
items.standfirst: We would like to hear people’s experiences accessing NHS dental treatment amid fears of ‘dental deserts’People living in deprived or rural communities are more likely to experience “dental deserts” with a lack of NHS dental services, according to analysis of NHS England data from the Local Government Association.For instance, Middlesborough, one of the most deprived local authorities in England, has just 10 NHS dental practices per 100,000 people, compared to Richmond upon Thames, among the least deprived, which has 28 per 100,000. Continue reading...
items.content: We would like to hear people’s experiences accessing NHS dental treatment amid fears of ‘dental deserts’People living in deprived or rural communities are more likely to experience “dental deserts” with a lack of NHS dental services, according to analysis of NHS England data from the Local Government Association.For instance, Middlesborough, one of the most deprived local authorities in England, has just 10 NHS dental practices per 100,000 people, compared to Richmond upon Thames, among the least deprived, which has 28 per 100,000. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Guardian seeks experiences accessing NHS dental treatment amid "dental deserts" fears.
Analysis of NHS England data shows deprived areas have fewer NHS dental practices.
Middlesborough has 10 NHS dental practices per 100,000 people.
Richmond upon Thames has 28 NHS dental practices per 100,000 people.
The Local Government Association analyzed the NHS England data.

clusters.title: Humans inhale as much as 68,000 microplastic particles daily, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Humans inhale thousands of microplastic particles daily

items.title: Humans inhale as much as 68,000 microplastic particles daily, study finds
items.standfirst: Particles are small enough to burrow into lungs, says report, with health impacts ‘more substantial than we realize’Every breath people take in their homes or car probably contains significant amounts of microplastics small enough to burrow deep into lungs, new peer-reviewed research finds, bringing into focus a little understood route of exposure and health threat.The study, published in the journal Plos One, estimates humans can inhale as much as 68,000 tiny plastic particles daily. Previous studies have identified larger pieces of airborne microplastics, but those are not as much of a health threat because they do not hang in the air as long, or move as deep into the pulmonary system. Continue reading...
items.content: Particles are small enough to burrow into lungs, says report, with health impacts ‘more substantial than we realize’Every breath people take in their homes or car probably contains significant amounts of microplastics small enough to burrow deep into lungs, new peer-reviewed research finds, bringing into focus a little understood route of exposure and health threat.The study, published in the journal Plos One, estimates humans can inhale as much as 68,000 tiny plastic particles daily. Previous studies have identified larger pieces of airborne microplastics, but those are not as much of a health threat because they do not hang in the air as long, or move as deep into the pulmonary system. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Humans inhale up to 68,000 microplastic particles daily, according to a study.
Particles are small enough to burrow into lungs, the study found.
The study was published in the journal PLOS One.
Previous studies identified larger airborne microplastics.
Larger microplastics are not as much of a health threat.

items.title: Malawi set to run out of TB drugs in a month after US, UK and others cut aid
items.standfirst: Gains in cutting deaths from tuberculosis at risk as health officials warn clinics forced to ration drugs and testingMalawi is facing a critical shortage of tuberculosis drugs, with health officials warning that stocks will run out by the end of September.It comes just months after the World Health Organization (WHO) revealed that the country had successfully reduced tuberculosis (TB) cases by 40% over the past decade. items.content: Gains in cutting deaths from tuberculosis at risk as health officials warn clinics forced to ration drugs and testingMalawi is facing a critical shortage of tuberculosis drugs, with health officials warning that stocks will run out by the end of September.It comes just months after the World Health Organization (WHO) revealed that the country had successfully reduced tuberculosis (TB) cases by 40% over the past decade. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Malawi is set to run out of TB drugs within a month.
Health officials warn clinics will ration drugs and testing.
The country reduced TB cases by 40% in the last decade.
The shortage comes after aid cuts from the US and UK.
The World Health Organization revealed the reduction in TB cases.

clusters.title: 'Our hot homes are making our children sick'
clusters.neutral_headline: Hot homes are making children sick in England

items.title: 'Our hot homes are making our children sick'
items.standfirst: Some five million children - over half of those in England - are living in homes at risk of overheating.
items.content: Some five million children - over half of those in England - are living in homes at risk of overheating.

ai_summary: Some five million children in England live in homes at risk of overheating.
Over half of children in England are at risk.
Overheating homes pose a health risk to children.
The number of children at risk is significant.
The issue is a growing concern.

clusters.title: Spain and Portugal wildfires drive worst EU season on record
clusters.neutral_headline: Wildfires in Spain and Portugal create worst EU season

items.title: Spain and Portugal wildfires drive worst EU season on record
items.standfirst: Wildfires have scorched southern Europe and new research suggests climate change played a major role.
items.content: Wildfires have scorched southern Europe and new research suggests climate change played a major role.

ai_summary: Wildfires have scorched southern Europe.
New research suggests climate change played a major role.
Spain and Portugal experienced significant wildfires.
The EU is facing its worst wildfire season on record.
Climate change is a contributing factor.

clusters.title: Overdiagnosis of children overlooks that growing up is ‘messy and uneven’, says Jeremy Hunt
clusters.neutral_headline: Overdiagnosis of children is a concern

items.title: Overdiagnosis of children overlooks that growing up is ‘messy and uneven’, says Jeremy Hunt
items.standfirst: Former health secretary wants to see an overhaul of special educational needs and disabilities system in EnglandChildren and young people are being overdiagnosed with mental health conditions in a society that has lost sight of the reality that child development is “messy and uneven”, the former health secretary Jeremy Hunt has said.He is the latest senior figure to add his voice to calls for a radical overhaul of the special educational needs and disabilities (Send) system in England. Continue reading...
items.content: Former health secretary wants to see an overhaul of special educational needs and disabilities system in EnglandChildren and young people are being overdiagnosed with mental health conditions in a society that has lost sight of the reality that child development is “messy and uneven”, the former health secretary Jeremy Hunt has said.He is the latest senior figure to add his voice to calls for a radical overhaul of the special educational needs and disabilities (Send) system in England. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jeremy Hunt says overdiagnosis overlooks child development.
He wants an overhaul of the special educational needs system.
Children and young people are being overdiagnosed.
Child development is "messy and uneven," according to Hunt.
Hunt is a former health secretary.

clusters.title: Denmark issues first apology over forced contraception of Greenlandic women
clusters.neutral_headline: Denmark apologizes for forced contraception in Greenland

items.title: Denmark issues first apology over forced contraception of Greenlandic women
items.standfirst: Prime minister admits ‘systemic discrimination’ after thousands of girls and women fitted with IUDs without consentDenmark’s prime minister, Mette Frederiksen, has apologised for the first time for the forced contraception scandal in which thousands of Greenlandic girls and women were fitted with contraceptive coils without their permission or knowledge.Describing it as “systemic discrimination” against women and girls by the Danish healthcare system, Frederiksen said that because they were Greenlandic they were subjected to “both physical and psychological harm”. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister admits ‘systemic discrimination’ after thousands of girls and women fitted with IUDs without consentDenmark’s prime minister, Mette Frederiksen, has apologised for the first time for the forced contraception scandal in which thousands of Greenlandic girls and women were fitted with contraceptive coils without their permission or knowledge.Describing it as “systemic discrimination” against women and girls by the Danish healthcare system, Frederiksen said that because they were Greenlandic they were subjected to “both physical and psychological harm”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Denmark issued its first apology over forced contraception.
Thousands of Greenlandic women were fitted with IUDs without consent.
The prime minister admitted "systemic discrimination."
The Danish healthcare system caused physical and psychological harm.
The apology was for the forced contraception scandal.

clusters.title: Seven-week wait for some red flag cancer patients 'frustrating'
clusters.neutral_headline: Seven-week wait for cancer patients is frustrating

items.title: Seven-week wait for some red flag cancer patients 'frustrating'
items.standfirst: The target set by the Department of Health for patients red flagged for breast cancer to be assessed is 14 days.
items.content: The target set by the Department of Health for patients red flagged for breast cancer to be assessed is 14 days.

ai_summary: Some red flag cancer patients face a seven-week wait.
The Department of Health set a 14-day assessment target.
The target is for patients red flagged for breast cancer.
The long wait times are considered frustrating.
The assessment target is not being met.

clusters.title: NHS to lose out on new drugs, pharma firm warns
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS to lose out on new drugs, pharma firm warns

items.title: NHS to lose out on new drugs, pharma firm warns
items.standfirst: The claims from pharmaceutical giant Novartis comes amid a row over drug pricing deals.
items.content: The claims from pharmaceutical giant Novartis comes amid a row over drug pricing deals.

ai_summary: The NHS will lose out on new drugs, a pharma firm warns.
The warning comes from pharmaceutical giant Novartis.
The warning is amid a row over drug pricing deals.
Novartis is concerned about drug availability.
The drug pricing deals are a point of contention.
